He goes on to say: Bread is not united to Christ⁷s Body in the unity of one Person, but as nearly as possible to that union (p. 224). If I at all understand his theory, it runs thus: Every sign receives a certain figurative entity of the thing it signifies, and in proportion as the sign proceeds from a higher authority, this entity becomes more perfectly present. Our fancy may consider a lamb as the image of Christ, and it then is Christ — to a certain extent. But the Paschal lamb was much rnore so3 and the highest possible perfection was reached, when Christ said of the bread: This is my Body.
